Marvel's latest blockbuster is an action-packed delight, says Niall Whitehead

Review: White God

Dogs rise up against humans in a Hungarian film that manages to be both grippingly entertaining and a disturbingly relevant parable, says Matthew Edwards

Review: Lost River

Despite harsh reviews, Ryan Gosling's dreamlike yet violent directorial debut is worth seeking out, says Matthew Edwards

If you've never seen live-action manga, you're missing out, says Ida Sjoberg

Review: Cinderella

The live action Cinderella is conventional but fun, says Gemma Horton

York Human Rights Film Festival Review: The Square

An award-winning documentary provides an eyewitness depiction of the Egyptian revolution. Rosemary Collins reviews

Review: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel

A star-studded cast all get their moment to shine in the second instalment of the charming film series about elderly Brits in India, says Katy Sandalls

Review: Catch Me Daddy

This British honour killing drama is a bleak and brutal Yorkshire western, says Sophie Worning.

Review: Still Alice

Julianne Moore deserved her Oscar for her depiction of an Early-onset Alzheimer's patient in a powerful but sometimes laboured drama, says Rosemary Collins

Review: Love Is Strange

John Lithgow and Alfred Molina play an elderly couple who run into difficulties after a late-in-life marriage. Sophie Worning reviews what happens next.

Review: Fifty Shades of Grey

The eagerly-awaited BDSM blockbuster has finally hit our screens... and it's one of the worst films Will Murray has ever seen

Review: Selma

The emotionally powerful and politically timely Martin Luther King biopic deserved more recognition at the Academy Awards, argues Liz Tresidder.

Review: Shaun the Sheep Movie

The latest Aardman animation is the funniest film of the year so far, says Rhys Thompson.

Review: Blackhat

Michael Mann's cybercrime thriller is a waste of a brilliant concept, says Tom Parkes

Review: Kingsman: The Secret Service

Matthew Vaughn's spy romp is an idiosyncratic thrill ride, says Thomas Shutt.

Review: Ex Machina

A scientist tries to discover whether a robot can pass for human in a psychological thriller that asks disturbing questions about our reliance on technology. Tom Parkes reviews

Review: Mortdecai

Ida Sjoberg gives zero stars to the 'fascinatingly awful' Johnny Depp caper Mortdecai.

Review: Inherent Vice

Incomprehensible, convoluted, and marginally brilliant. Alex Killeen warns that if you're not ready to invest, Inherent Vice is not the one for you.

Review: Big Hero 6

Disney's follow-up to Frozen is a superhero adventure with surprising emotional depth. Niall Whitehead reviews.

Review: A Most Violent Year

A businessman struggles to stick to the right path in 1980s New York. Molly McElwee reviews.

Review: Beyond Clueless

A new film about the world of teenage cinema suffers from the same identity crises as its high-schooler heroes, says Jasmin Hayward.

Review: Whiplash

This drumming drama bends the music film genre with sheer intensity, says Alfie Packham

Review: Testament of Youth

Alicia Vikander gives a flawless performance in a powerful adaptation of Vera Brittain's First World War memoir, says Liz Tresidder

Review: Into the Woods

A stellar cast can't make up for a lack of narrative drive in this adaptation of Stephen Sondheim's fairy tale musical, says Rhys Thompson.

Review: Birdman

Michael Keaton gives a towering performance in a stunning film about a washed-up actor's seemingly doomed comeback, says Thomas Shutt

Review: The Theory of Everything

The biopic of Stephen and Jane Hawking does its subjects a disservice, says Thomas Shutt.

Review: American Sniper

Bradley Cooper gives an Oscar-nominated performance as the most glorified sniper in US army history. Tom Parkes reviews.

Review: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb

The late Robin Williams gives his last performance in the latest Night at the Museum adventure. Minal Daswani reviews.

Review: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies

The closing chapter to Peter Jackson's Hobbit saga has arrived and Alex Killeen finds that many of the series' nagging problems still persist

Review: Paddington

The Peruvian bear's fans are in for a treat with the big-screen film of his adventures, says Gemma Horton.
